<ce:section-title>Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">We report on the synthesis and crystal structures of two new zinc coordination polymers: [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(oba)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(azpy)(dmf)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6DMF (azpy<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4,4′-azopyridine) (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) and [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(oba)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bpe)]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2DMF<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (bpe<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>trans</ce:italic>-1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene) (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>). Compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> exhibits one-dimensional structure, and Compound <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> exhibits a three-dimensional structure that is interwoven by heteroorganic oba and bpe bridges. We report on the synthesis and crystal structures of two new zinc coordination polymers: [Zn2(oba)2(azpy)(dmf)2]·6DMF (azpy=4,4′-azopyridine) (3) and [Zn2(oba)2(bpe)]·2DMF·4H2O (bpe=

This structure, which is constructed by connected two-dimensional frameworks of [Zn2(oba)2] with bpe bridges, has a high porosity with a density of only 0.53gcm−3.

elements.clean_text:
Abstract
We report on the synthesis and crystal structures of two new zinc coordination polymers with 4,4′-oxybis(benzoate) (oba) ligands. Single crystals of [Zn2(oba)2(azpy)(dmf)2]·6DMF(azpy=4,4′-azopyridine) and [Zn2(oba)2(bpe)]·2DMF·4H2O (bpe=
trans-1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene) were prepared by treatment of Zn(CH3COO)2
·2H2O with the H2oba and bis-pyridine type ligands, azpy and bpe, respectively, in DMF. Compound [Zn2(oba)2(azpy)(dmf)2]·6DMF has a unique ladder structure comprising of heteroorganic bridges, in which the Zn–oba chains construct the side rails, while the Zn–azpy–Zn parts construct the rungs of the ladder framework. Despite the large size of the cavities, these ladder chains stack without interpenetration, and the cavities in the ladder framework are partially connected to create one-dimensional channel-like cavities. Compound [Zn2(oba)2(bpe)]·2DMF·4H2O exhibits a three-dimensional coordination framework that is comprised of heteroorganic bridges. The framework is interwoven by two-dimensional layers of [Zn2(oba)2] and the Zn2–bpe chains. The three-dimensional framework, which contains large cavities, about 13×11Å2 in area, has a high porosity and a density of only 0.53gcm−3.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The construction of coordination polymers with new network motifs is of current interest for the development of new functional materials and in fundamental studies of crystal engineering and supramolecular chemistry . In the synthesis of new network structures, coordination polymers constructed from heteroorganic bridges are challenging subjects because any synthetic method used needs to take into account the designed construction involving versatile coordination frameworks . Nevertheless, coordination networks constructed from heteroorganic bridges are rare because of the difficulty in achieving the rational incorporation of different organic ligands.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction
The construction of coordination polymers with new network motifs is of current interest for the development of new functional materials and in fundamental studies of crystal engineering and supramolecular chemistry . In the synthesis of new network structures, coordination polymers constructed from heteroorganic bridges are challenging subjects because any synthetic method used needs to take into account the designed construction involving versatile coordination frameworks . Nevertheless, coordination networks constructed from heteroorganic bridges are rare because of the difficulty in achieving the rational incorporation of different organic ligands.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Bis-benzoate-type bridges have been exploited in the synthesis of many coordination networks . For example, [M<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(1,4-benzenedicarboxylate)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]-type frameworks have been prepared and characterized . The unique feature of this type of network structure is the presence of square cavities, which are retained without collapsing and exhibit porous functionalities such as gas adsorption and heterogeneous catalysts. Although it has been shown that the two-dimensional layers can be connected by additional neutral ligands, structural characterization from X-ray single crystal analysis has not been carried out.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Bis-benzoate-type bridges have been exploited in the synthesis of many coordination networks . For example, [M2(1,4-benzenedicarboxylate)2]-type frameworks have been prepared and characterized . The unique feature of this type of network structure is the presence of square cavities, which are retained without collapsing and exhibit porous functionalities such as gas adsorption and heterogeneous catalysts. Although it has been shown that the two-dimensional layers can be connected by additional neutral ligands, structural characterization from X-ray single crystal analysis has not been carried out.

<ce:para view="all">We have investigated coordination polymers with chalcogen atoms in the organic bridging ligands , and have reported on two coordination polymers, [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(oba)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(dmf)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2DMF (oba<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4,4′-oxybis(benzoate)) (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and [Zn(oba)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)] (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) in a recent communication. These two compounds show reversible structural transformations depending on the present solvents. In ongoing work, we have successfully created two new zinc coordination polymers constructed from heteroorganic bridges: oba- and bis-pyridine-type ligands, i.e., <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic>-1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene (bpe) and 4,4′-azopyridine (azpy). elements.clean_text:
We have investigated coordination polymers with chalcogen atoms in the organic bridging ligands , and have reported on two coordination polymers, [Zn2(oba)2(dmf)2]·2DMF (oba=4,4′-oxybis(benzoate)) (1) and [Zn(oba)(H2O)] (2) in a recent communication. These two compounds show reversible structural transformations depending on the present solvents. In ongoing work, we have successfully created two new zinc coordination polymers constructed from heteroorganic bridges: oba- and bis-pyridine-type ligands, i.e., trans-1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene (bpe) and 4,4′-azopyridine (azpy). Despite the similar structures of the two ancillary ligands, the structures of the resulting compounds, [Zn2(oba)2(azpy)(dmf)2]·6DMF (azpy=4,4′-azopyridine) (3) and [Zn2(oba)2(bpe)]·2DMF·4H2O (4), show different network structures. The network motifs of these compounds are illustrated in 
. This paper describes the synthesis and crystal structures of coordination polymers 3 and 4.

<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl1"></ce:float-anchor>. The carboxylate ligands of the oba group bind to the zinc center via a four-membered chelation, in which the two Zn–O bond distances differ significantly: Zn(1)–O(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.091(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, Zn(1)–O(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.231(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, Zn(1)–O(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.283(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, and Zn(1)–O(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.096(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. In addition to the four carboxylate oxygen atoms, an additional oxygen atom of a dmf molecule and a pyridine nitrogen atom of an azpy group are coordinated to the zinc center. The above coordination center is based on the markedly distorted octahedron observed. This is due to the four-membered carboxylate chelation, in which the N(1) atom of the azpy group and the O(3) atom of the oba group occupy the axial positions at the N(1)–Zn(1)–O(3) group with a bond angle of 151.2(1)°.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion
Diffusion of a DMF solution of H2oba and azpy into a DMF solution of Zn(CH3COO)2
·2H2O yielded single crystals of Compound 3. An ORTEP view around the zinc centers is shown in 
a. The selected bond distances and angles are listed in 
. The carboxylate ligands of the oba group bind to the zinc center via a four-membered chelation, in which the two Zn–O bond distances differ significantly: Zn(1)–O(1)=2.091(3)Å, Zn(1)–O(2)=2.231(3)Å, Zn(1)–O(3)=2.283(4)Å, and Zn(1)–O(4)=2.096(3)Å. In addition to the four carboxylate oxygen atoms, an additional oxygen atom of a dmf molecule and a pyridine nitrogen atom of an azpy group are coordinated to the zinc center. The above coordination center is based on the markedly distorted octahedron observed. This is due to the four-membered carboxylate chelation, in which the N(1) atom of the azpy group and the O(3) atom of the oba group occupy the axial positions at the N(1)–Zn(1)–O(3) group with a bond angle of 151.2(1)°.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Each zinc center is bridged by an oba group to yield a one-dimensional chain directed along the <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>-axis. The chains are further connected by azpy bridges to yield a ladder-type one-dimensional structure, as shown in b, in which the Zn–oba chains construct the “side rails”, and the Zn–azpy–Zn parts construct the “rungs” of the ladder framework. The Zn⋯Zn distances bridged by the oba and azpy groups are 14.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and 13.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively, which form large cavities with an effective area of about 12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>11<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>. The cavities in the framework exhibit a compressed octahedral structure at the apexes of the four zinc atoms and two ether–oxygen atoms. The coordinating dmf molecules protrude in the same direction as the corresponding side rail.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Each zinc center is bridged by an oba group to yield a one-dimensional chain directed along the b-axis. The chains are further connected by azpy bridges to yield a ladder-type one-dimensional structure, as shown in b, in which the Zn–oba chains construct the “side rails”, and the Zn–azpy–Zn parts construct the “rungs” of the ladder framework. The Zn⋯Zn distances bridged by the oba and azpy groups are 14.1Å and 13.1Å, respectively, which form large cavities with an effective area of about 12×11Å2. The cavities in the framework exhibit a compressed octahedral structure at the apexes of the four zinc atoms and two ether–oxygen atoms. The coordinating dmf molecules protrude in the same direction as the corresponding side rail.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The thermal stability of the highly porous framework of Compound <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> was estimated using thermogravimetric analysis (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig5"></ce:float-anchor>). The removal of the guest DMF molecules was observed below about 200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (observed 18%, calcd 21%). ). The removal of the guest DMF molecules was observed below about 200°C (observed 18%, calcd 21%). Experimental
Preparations of the compounds
The compound [Zn2(oba)2(azpy)(dmf)2]·6DMF (3) was prepared by diffusion of a DMF solution (200mL) of H2oba (5.2g, 20mmol) and azpy (6.0g, 20mmol) into a DMF solution (200mL) of Zn(CH3COO)2
·2H2O (2.2g, 10mmol). Red columnar crystals were formed within a period of one week, and these were collected by filtration under a nitrogen atmosphere because of the highly moisture sensitivity. Elemental Anal. Calc. for C44H62N6O24Zn2 ([Zn2(oba)2(azpy)(dmf)2]·12H2O): C, 44.21; H, 5.25; N, 7.06. Found: C, 44.82; H, 5.19; N, 6.69%.

·2H2O (2.2g, 10mmol). Colorless cubic crystals were formed within a period of one week, and these were collected by filtration under a nitrogen atmosphere because of the highly moisture sensitivity. <ce:section-title>Crystal structure determination</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">For both Compounds <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, a suitable single crystal was sealed in a glass capillary tube along with its mother liquid. Data collection was carried out using a Rigaku CCD mercury system fitted with a monochromatic Mo<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Kα radiation source (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.71069<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) at room temperature for Compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and at −40<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for Compound <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>. The X-ray data obtained is shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl3"></ce:float-anchor>. Six preliminary data frames were measured at increments of <ce:italic>ω</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.5° to assess the crystal quality and preliminary unit cell parameters. The intensity of the images was also measured at intervals of <ce:italic>ω</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.5°. The intensity of the images was integrated using the Crystal Clear software package, and an empirical absorption correction was applied to the data. The structures were resolved using a direct method (<ce:small-caps>sir</ce:small-caps>-92). For Compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, all the nonhydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically using the full-matrix least-squares technique except for the crystalline solvent molecules, which were refined isotropically. The geometrical hydrogen atoms were placed in idealized positions, and were included, but not refined. For Compound <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, the nonhydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically using the full-matrix least-squares technique except for the crystalline solvent DMF molecules, which were not refined, but were included. All calculations were performed using the TEXSAN crystallographic software package (Molecular Structure Corporation, USA).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure determination
For both Compounds 3 and 4, a suitable single crystal was sealed in a glass capillary tube along with its mother liquid. Data collection was carried out using a Rigaku CCD mercury system fitted with a monochromatic MoKα radiation source (λ
=0.71069Å) at room temperature for Compound 3 and at −40°C for Compound 4. The X-ray data obtained is shown in 
. Six preliminary data frames were measured at increments of ω
=0.5° to assess the crystal quality and preliminary unit cell parameters. The intensity of the images was also measured at intervals of ω
=0.5°. The intensity of the images was integrated using the Crystal Clear software package, and an empirical absorption correction was applied to the data. The structures were resolved using a direct method (sir-92). For Compound 3, all the nonhydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically using the full-matrix least-squares technique except for the crystalline solvent molecules, which were refined isotropically. The geometrical hydrogen atoms were placed in idealized positions, and were included, but not refined. For Compound 4, the nonhydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically using the full-matrix least-squares technique except for the crystalline solvent DMF molecules, which were not refined, but were included. All calculations were performed using the TEXSAN crystallographic software package (Molecular Structure Corporation, USA).
